content: The "Drinking Water Right-to-Know Act of 1999" requires testing for radium 224 in drinking water within 48 hours of sampling. Community water systems must provide consumer confidence reports. Section 1414(c)(4) of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to require the Administrator to provide a report on the level of contaminants in drinking water that may be difficult to detect and pose a public health concern. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to address contaminants in finished water, with specific regulations outlined for providing protection against such contaminants. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to require public water systems to mail consumer confidence reports to residential and non-residential consumers. The Safe Drinking Water Act now requires public water systems to provide detailed information on detected contaminants and their potential health effects, including effects on vulnerable populations like children and pregnant women. Sources of contaminants must also be disclosed. The Safe Drinking Water Act mandates public water systems to disclose information on detected contaminants, their health effects, and sources. Consumers are provided with details on contaminants in drinking water and any health advisories issued. The Safe Drinking Water Act requires public water systems to notify consumers of newly detected contamination with potential health effects within 30 days of discovery. The Safe Drinking Water Act mandates public water systems to inform consumers of any contamination exceeding the maximum contaminant level goal within 30 days of detection, whether it is a regulated or unregulated contaminant. The term 'consumer' includes customers of public water systems. The Safe Drinking Water Act requires public water systems to notify customers of any contamination exceeding the maximum contaminant level goal within 30 days of detection. The term 'consumer' refers to both customers of public water systems and the ultimate consumers of the drinking water. SEC. 4. SOURCE WATER ASSESSMENTS. Section 1453(a)(2) of the Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to assess the susceptibility of public water systems to contaminants regulated under national primary drinking water regulations or listed as unregulated contaminants. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for states to identify and monitor contaminants that pose a threat to public health, including known or suspected sources of pollution that may impact groundwater quality. The curr_chunk specifies that assessments under the Safe Drinking Water Act should apply to various areas like wellheads and watersheds, and involve public cooperation. Documentation related to assessments must be made publicly available. Plans for these assessments must be developed within a year of the enactment of the paragraph. The State must submit a plan to the Administrator for carrying out assessments under the Safe Drinking Water Act, with updates required every 5 years.
